course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Cultures and Values: Community, Conflict and Resolution
course.description: Even in the age of globalization and highly advanced communication and transportation technologies, human beings still belong to different groups, each with its own set of identifying markers and priorities. These human identities and groupings are fundamentally informed by their historical past. This course is an exploration of human society through a historical analysis of the roots of these broad categories that we use to organize ourselves. The first value of “identity and community” examines the formation and changes in basic categories of differences in human society. These categories include ethnic, religious, and linguistic differences that gave rise to varying layers of identities that each individual may possess. Exploring the second value, “contact and conflict,” entails analyzing how these differences in identities caused competition over ideologies and resources. Finally, understanding the value of “justice and resolution” is an investigation of the ways through which human beings have devised ways to resolve conflicts and disputes within and between groups.

Week 11a: Mid-Term Break
Week 11b: Delivery of Justice
Week 12: Political Mediation

The content of the lecture is interesting, especially under the current political situation. There are so many social phenomena that you didn't realize but did happen in your daily life.

For example, how do we draw our boundaries? Would prefer to describe yourself as a son, student of HKUST, a citizen of HK V.S. China, or Asian? Even do we migrate into Japan, will we be accepted by the foreigners even though we are politically defined as Japanese? In Hong Kong, there are many races of people such as the Pakistanis, Indians, and the mainlander. Why still many Hong Kongers did not accept them? What makes us classify someone as an "outsider"?

In terms of culture, the lecture content covers different cultures, ranging from Eze, France, Shirakawa-go, Fujian tulou, Regensburg, Venice, Qingming shanghe tu. It also covers the way culture transmit across the physical boundaries and the economic cycle of the ancient world, the function of the village, class, government, races, cities, states.

Not only the historical events, but it also covers some current social issues. For example, the nuclear waste of Japan, WWII, nationalism, BLM, covid-19, and the US election, which will definitely make you have a better understanding and the way we look at our world.

10% quiz: 12個無限attempt quiz，可以sem頭一次過做曬，唔啱做到啱，有需要先睇materials做quiz

10% workshop: 5個workshops，平均每兩星期一個，5%出席，5% workshop homework，內容係逐步要你砌篇essay，第一個workshop揀題目寫thesis，跟著寫introduction...如此類推。個人miss咗一次workshop同一份hw，所以8/10。hw有交有分，fyi我喺交draft essay(workshop 4)先改題目砍掉重練，只能怪自己懶，前3份hw交垃圾只求過骨

20% in-class quiz: sorry幫唔到你地，但唔好意思Lecture notes都幫唔到你地

10% Discussion: 我剩係參與咗2/3個discussion，有參與嘅discussion都留咗一個300-400字嘅言，冇覆人，另外syllabus寫臨近deadline先留言會斟酌扣分

50% essay: 交draft essay用咗兩日做，900字求過骨，重頭戲係收到instructor feedback後要改曬佢要你改嘅嘢，佢要咩就比咩佢，因為當中有25%係計你收到feedback後，要解釋你根據個feedback改咗乜。final submission都用咗兩日做，接近maximum字數

總結: workshop相關20%要執曬，workshop hw建議認真做；lecture quiz唔評論；Discussion有興致都可以同其他同學投入討論；essay要花時間滿足instructor要求，如果workshop有認真做hw應該會比我用更少時間完成。好似我咁B range就滿足就只需要sem尾努力下，但望返轉頭自己hw同discussion努力啲結果可能會更好，不過是但啦

reviews.author: ChloeYu
reviews.title: Tutorial teacher determines everything
reviews.comment_content:
The contents are fruitful and interesting.
Week 1
Course Introduction: Environmental forces and human society – location, climate, and people

Week 2
Identity and Community: Family
Family is the most basic unit of social organization, but what exactly constitutes a family? Who “belongs” to a family, and why? What are the different ways through which human beings organize themselves into kinship units? 

Week 3
Identity and Community: Villages, Cities and States
Moving beyond the family, we start developing tribal organizations that may be local or regional but transcend the immediate family. 

Week 4
Identity and community: Ethnicity and Nation
Ethnic groups and nations as “Imagined communities” that nevertheless have people believe they all belong together in one natural grouping.

Week 5
Identity and community: Religion
Deity worship, supernatural beliefs, and how these concepts bind and divide humanity and helped organize human society. 

Week 6
Identity and community: Class
Who owns the means of production? Who gets the lion’s share of income in a given society? Why did class become an issue and how has that changed the way we view our world?

Week 7
Contact and conflict: Trade and Taxation
From barter to global free trade, the exchange of goods and government taxation of production is one of the fundamental pillars of government. 

Week 8 – March 27, 2023
Contact and conflict: War
War is the continuation of politics by other means. Fighting over resources, people, and beliefs is also one of the fundamental drivers of human change.

Week 9 – April 3, 2023
Contact and conflict: Rebellion
Whether from within or without, rebellions (and revolutions) often had tremendous impact on the societies in which they took place.

Week 10
Justice and resolution: Delivery of justice
One of the primary functions of a government is the deliverance of some form of justice – to arbitrate disputes and resolve differences.

Week 11 – April 24, 2023
Justice and resolution: Democracy

reviews.comment_teaching:
Lawerence actually doesn't have much accent problem in the lecture.  
He is open to students' questions, either about the essay or the lecture.
However, there are two things that you may find not appealing about his teaching:
Firstly, his PowerPoint slide used are mainly only images, and seldom text. Therefore, you may want to review lecture videos again after the lecture/before the quiz to understand what is happening.
Secondly, he teaches at a rather slow pace. This one is quite neutral, since some students may take time to understand. If you think you can understand everything quickly, you may turn on 2x in lecture recording.

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload of this course is generally fine.

For the online discussion, just put your idea as soon as possible so that you are not repeating others' idea. Reply to others regularly, and maybe try to reply the replies to your post.

For the Writing Workshop, make sure you do your work and listen to your tutor's feedback (unless they are really bad lol). There is not much I can say here.

For the Essay, you can actually finish the draft early and modify it progressively as the semester goes on, according to your tutor's feedback. Of course, this really depends on your motivation to do so.

For the Quiz, have fun doing HUMArathon before and note down what Lawerence said. As I said in the teaching section, his slides are mainly images so you have to watch lecture videos to understand better and refresh your mind. The quiz is 20 MCQs with no turning-back policy on Canvas.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Zhang is a nice professor, he includes inclusive contents in class and explains them in detail, which makes students easy to get what he means. He also posts a great many reading materials for each week, which is a good chance to expand our reading scope and look for fresh ideas.

The instructor of tutorial is also very helpful and patient, she provides lots of opportunities for us to discuss and share and I could always learn a lot from each lesson. good!
reviews.comment_grading:
This course takes a quiz, a final essay, tutorial work, 3 online discussions into consideration.

For the quiz, it is important to pay attention to each detail in the slides, including those which seem to be very easy, better read them all before the quiz.

For the essay, I think as long as you follow what is taught in the tutorial and do enough individual thinking (take advantage of the online discussions), it is not hard to get A range.

For the tut, do attend each one and listen carefully to the instructor!!
reviews.comment_workload:
I think workload is reasonable for a HUMA course, not that heavy.

lectures deliver all the important and basic concepts of this course while tutorials is a very good platform to learn how to write a perfect essay, especially useful for mainland students who didn't have much essay writing practice in the past.

Personally, I find the 'online discussion' extremely useful as it stimulates me to explore wider and deeper under one simple topic, by reading other students' comments, I was inspired by many unique ideas and some language techniques, which help me to come up with many personal ideas.

Even though some people write thousands of words under one single discussion, which makes it a huge work and takes a long time, I strongly think this process is necessary and you won't feel the time passing by while you write it because you will definitely have a lot to share on that platform!! enjoy it!

reviews.author: therock
reviews.title: easy A for experienced essay writers
reviews.comment_content: Interesting content, even though kinda all over the place. We cover sooo many topics and case studies that it's kinda annoying, but you're bound to learn something that interests you and will stick. If you've taken history/politics before, a lot of the case studies will be semi-review, though Lawrence goes in greater depth so you still need to pay attention as he brings up the dumbest small details in his midterm (ex. a question we had was "Hong Xiuquan thought he was: a) jesus' brother, b) jesus' cousin, etc.)
reviews.comment_teaching: Lawrence is an interesting species of his own. After about 10 mins of him talking you can tell he went to Harvard (don't worry, if you don't figure it out yourself, he'll manage to remind you in every lecture, talking about his 'colleague from Harvard', 'professor from Harvard', etc). Half of the time it feels like he's flexing his knowledge rather than trying to actually teach you something useful. That being said, he is clearly very intelligent and a good lecturer. Still can be annoying though, especially when he trails off. I once saw the TA asleep during this kind of rambling session. Oh and don't think about talking in his lecture, he'll be sassy about it and call you out. Every. Single. Time. Better to sleep :)
reviews.comment_grading: Half of the grading is based on your essay, so if you can write a decent essay you're good. The one I wrote was definitely not one of my best, and I still got an A+, so clearly the standards aren't crazy high. International students have an edge here, as we've written a lot more essays in high school. Midterm I got 18/20 (mean was around 13). Full workshop attendance + full marks on the online tasks. Not sure what I scored in the discussions, but I posted around 7-8 comments for each one.
reviews.comment_workload: Not that bad, lecture is only once a week and attendance isn't taken. Workshops were every 3ish weeks, and our tutor let us out early each time. Most work went into the canvas discussions to be honest. Studying for midterm and writing the essay don't take too much time if you're efficient about it. Don't bother with the reading material by the way, no one reads it and it's pointless. There was 1/20 question on the midterm from the readings, but it was quite logical so people who didn't even read it could have guessed it easily.

reviews.author: SQ Flyer
reviews.title: Having a societal & ideological sense matters
reviews.comment_content:
For the entire course content, a total of three major parts is included.
Identity and community is the key focus for the course and the quiz, also for your term essay.

For details please refer to the attachment.

I would say some of the lecture content are quite interesting and inspiring given that you have some background knowledge or sense on them. Identity conflicts between ethnic groups around the world in the past are still quite relatable to today's global affairs. You can see well the examples are quite all-rounded and carefully selected, like the Israel-Palestine conflicts last month, the US Parliament incident this year can show how identity in different aspects influence the ideological competition in these days.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think Prof. Lawrence Zhang provide a detailed insight on different aspects of identity issues, the associated historical & ideological conflicts of the medieval and post-modern times, and the respective resolutions and trends.

The course is somehow like a social science or history class rather than a rigorous humanities class I would say, since the topics are more like related to the historical development of the civilized society in medieval China & Europe, viewing the topics from a historical and socio-political point of view may help.

I would say the topics chosen are fine, the problem is the professor loves to show lots of picture (without words) in the class presentation and somehow the examples illustrated like those European Empires, Chinese royal states (he talks so much on the 康熙皇帝 清朝官廳 those stuffs) may find unfamiliar for most local students. If you follow the real-time lectures, you may find difficult to follow given you need to jot extra notes and listen to what he says (especially he often uses very specific terminologies & uncommon vocabularies), and see the naughty kids kept yelling in the chat box !! so I suggest you to watch the after class lecture videos instead.

For the writing tutorial, my tutor Graham is quite supportive and he often provides useful feedbacks on your essay progress. I worked on a quite distinctive case and we found it enjoyable.
reviews.comment_grading:
Like the other HUMA 1000 courses, your essay almost defines your grade. See below.

Canvas Discussion * 3 10%
Writing workshop online activities (Canvas writing workshop quizzes) 10%
Writing workshop homework submission & attendance 10%
Course Quiz with 20 MCQs 20%
A thousand word term essay 50%

My grade:
Quiz 15/20 (Mean 14/20)
For other components I have no idea on the score.
Turns out an A.
I am quite satisfied with this.

Remark: I chose Prompt 1 (Identity politics demonstrating inclusiveness) as my essay topic.
(only I myself and another student in my tutorial group chose Prompt 1)

Most students chose Prompt 2.

I suggest students to take this course if you just can't get registered to 1000A/B, this course is comparatively less competitive or if you have some sense on social matters, then choose this course my majesty.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload really depends on the efforts you have placed on the term essay and the Canvas Discussion forum, and also your preparation for the course quiz in the final teaching week.

For me, I watched part of the lecture videos consecutively during Easter break, and some of the remaining videos I watched them around a week before the quiz. Because the quiz is open-book Multiple choice questions, you better prepare a tailor-made notes to jot down the definitions and examples illustrated during lectures.

For Canvas discussion forum, a total of three forums was assigned which lasted for two weeks each. You just shared your views promptly with supporting arguments and references, and replied to your tutorial students regularly. I saw someone replied crazily but I think it's just not necessary. For me, I posted 3 feeds on the first forum, 7 feeds on the second forum (about meritocracy) and only 2 feeds on the final forum. Not replying too late would be fine.

Your essay depends on how you defined the topic you would like to focus on from the essay prompts given. Before each writing tutorial, you were supposed to submit the Canvas workshop quizzes and should have submitted a partial contribution of your essay. The tutor then provided you the feedbacks. Just don't make silly mistakes and submit all on time will be fine.
The tutor and professor would send you timely emails on how you can work on your essay, and they are likely to discuss with you by appointment.

Suggestions on essay:
You better choose a topic focus and case that you are very familiar or confident with (for local I suggest working on local identity issue or those you have well heard of).
Don't bother defining your thesis in a very vague and unrealistic manner. There are lots of flexibility for you to show your views and supporting arguments promptly.

Or else you will be someone who always complain you are a revision jj and no nuinui, while that guy ends up very poor grade, delivering goods all day long and got brainwashed with sinovac

reviews.author: JKL
reviews.title: interesting class, cool professor
reviews.comment_content:
Covers a variety of topics, all which are very interesting. It gave me a new perspective on life and the way I view history and the future. I was able to understand my identity better, as well as others, and understand why people act the way they do. All the topics were somehow related back to our own experiences, which I enjoyed because it made understanding the content a lot easier. The prof would relate the content back to Hong Kong issues and society, which definitely makes people a lot more aware.

The tutorial content is unnecessary and a waste of time, especially if english is your first language. you go through a few classes just to learn how to write something persuasive... from introduction to conclusion. As an english speaking university this a waste of time and should only be offered to those who need it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very interesting to listen to! He's very well-spoken and relaxed. He makes a few jokes here and there, which lightens the mood. He's very straight to the point, which I appreciate about him since he doesn't write notes on his powerpoints, so you have to listen to him speak. All in all, I really appreciated the way he presented information.

I also hate when people start talking during his lectures, so I appreciate that he tells them to be quiet. Feels nice to have people called out.

He also plays music during breaks, which makes the atmosphere a lot nicer.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was okay. As long as you listen to the key points and focus on what he emphasizes on, you're good! The quiz was very fast and simple, if you listen during the lectures you'll remember a few things here and there, so it doesn't require much memorisation.
reviews.comment_workload:
The essay was really easy to write, but the required readings were shocking. There are some that are just one page, whereas others with 10+. I gave up near the end, and it didn't really matter because the content there wasn't tested on much. Even if it was, it wouldn't impact your grade that much. Just go to the lectures, it's the most efficient way to get a good grade. The readings were interesting though!

Discussions are also very straight forward, you just talk about your opinion on certain topics and reply to a few others, which may lead to some very interesting conversations!

The online quizzes that you have to submit is crazy simple... you don't even need to read the supporting document to understand how to answer the questions. What's annoying is the deadline - once you miss it you miss it. So I suggest doing all the online quizzes in one go.

reviews.comment_workload:
Overall, the workload is pretty heavy, given last semester I also had to take other heavy-workload courses such as MGMT2010 and ISOM2010.
However, as long as you manage time well and work consistently on the assignment due deadline dates through beginning to mid of course, you will be able to catch up on revising the final essay during the end of the term.


There are 3 Online Discussions throughout the semester (you have to post frequently bc your TA is going to check and review your comments, each discussion's deadline is approximately 12 days);

5 In Class Writing Workshops (Mandatory Attendance and make sure to come no more late than 15 minutes, otherwise you will lose your attendance mark), and for my tutorial section it was actually split into 2 groups (1st session comes earlier and 2nd section comes later). And you have to bring your own laptop too

Online Writing Workshops, do not submit late bc it may decrease your final grade.

Final essay - The most influential impact on your grade (it weighs for the half of final grade!). Make sure to not miss any assignments bc you need to revise it in short time before the final draft and exact final essay submission date. And you need to list your revision efforts in the front of final essay's cover page. If u submit the final essay late from the deadline, you may not get A range.

Quiz - This is the only part that is acceptable i think (and the small percentage so it is not that impactful as final essay). (I did poor on the quiz :(( ) But make sure u prepare the materials bc there is a lot of memorization cuz the quiz has many trapping questions. Quiz structure is informed through last lecture class bfr quiz and itsc email.

btw for my lecture class, the lecture attendance is not needed.
